#refugees.head()

%md
# Refugees' topic impact on news and Social Media

*Authors: Alberto Abreu, Josep Foradada and Íngrid Munné*

This paper is the result of the third project under the Data Analytics Bootcamp program at Ironhack Barcelona. In this project, we wanted to work on a topic that really motivated us to keep researching, learning, and furthermore, growing as data analysts but also as human-beings. Refugees is a topic that we are seeing both on social media and on mass-media, but there are some open questions that will be answered in this report. 

The structure of the paper is as follows. First, in Section 1 we introduced the topic, analyzing the evolution of refugee population by year and by country. We described the databases we have used to perform the analysis in Section 2.  Later on, we raised our questions in terms of data analysis based on this topic. Results and conclusions for each question are provided in Section 4. Then, general conclusions from our analysis are presented as well as the open questions that can still be researched.

msg.data:
Refugees’ topic impact on news and Social Media

Authors: Alberto Abreu, Josep Foradada and Íngrid Munné

This paper is the result of the third project under the Data Analytics Bootcamp program at Ironhack Barcelona. In this project, we wanted to work on a topic that really motivated us to keep researching, learning, and furthermore, growing as data analysts but also as human-beings. Refugees is a topic that we are seeing both on social media and on mass-media, but there are some open questions that will be answered in this report.

The structure of the paper is as follows. First, in Section 1 we introduced the topic, analyzing the evolution of refugee population by year and by country. We described the databases we have used to perform the analysis in Section 2. Later on, we raised our questions in terms of data analysis based on this topic. Results and conclusions for each question are provided in Section 4. Then, general conclusions from our analysis are presented as well as the open questions that can still be researched.

paragraphs.text:
%md 
## 1. Introduction
The term Refugee is defined by the Oxford Dictionary as: 

>a person who has escaped grom their own country for political, religious, or economic reasons because of a war or  political conflict. 

This is a topic that we can see and read on social media and also on newspaper. However, are we talking about all the refugees that are in the world? Is this equally covered both in social media and in Twitter. When we started working on the topic, we proposed two main questions: 

- What's the impact of refugee-related events in media (newspaper) and social media (Twitter)
- Once the event is raised, is there an equal coverage on Twitter and on newspaper? 

    * By total amount of information 
    * By timeperiod 
    
Before answering the questions, we wanted to dive deeper into the refugee population around the world, to quantify the situation and understand the problem out there. 

To be able to get these data, data from WorldBank Data has been retrieved to calculate the total refugee population and analyse the evolution. WorldBank Data is an association that has a division to collect data for financial and economic products from countries around the world. Since 1991 this entity is analyzing the refugee population by country of origin.

msg.data:
1. Introduction

The term Refugee is defined by the Oxford Dictionary as:

a person who has escaped grom their own country for political, religious, or economic reasons because of a war or political conflict.

This is a topic that we can see and read on social media and also on newspaper. However, are we talking about all the refugees that are in the world? Is this equally covered both in social media and in Twitter. When we started working on the topic, we proposed two main questions:

  • What’s the impact of refugee-related events in media (newspaper) and social media (Twitter)
  • Once the event is raised, is there an equal coverage on Twitter and on newspaper?
    • By total amount of information
    • By timeperiod

Before answering the questions, we wanted to dive deeper into the refugee population around the world, to quantify the situation and understand the problem out there.

To be able to get these data, data from WorldBank Data has been retrieved to calculate the total refugee population and analyse the evolution. WorldBank Data is an association that has a division to collect data for financial and economic products from countries around the world. Since 1991 this entity is analyzing the refugee population by country of origin.

paragraphs.title: Fig. 1 - Refugee population by year
paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT year, sum(number_refugees) AS number_of_refugees from refugees GROUP BY year

paragraphs.text:
%md
As can be seen from the Figure 1, there is a clear growth on the total amount of refugees since 2012, that has been nearly doubled the value in 2010. According to the information provided from World Bank Data, the countries were the most amount of refugees are the following ones: Syrian Arab Republic, Afghanistan, South Sudan, Myanmar, Somalia, Sudan, Democratic Republic of Congo, Central African Republic, Eritrea and Burundi. 

We want to take a look at this data to see if this is a topic that should be clearly spoken in our daily-lives (Figure 2). It should be noticed from here that these results are from country of origin and not from country 

(( IMPORTANT: SPECIFY THAT THESE ARE THE COUNTRY OF ORIGIN)

paragraphs.text:
%md
### 1.1. Databases Used
In order to develop this project, several databases have been used. First of all, Twitter API to get the tweets on this topic. Secondly, NewsAPI has been used as a source to get news from newspapers and digital newspapers. Later on, web scraping on diferent webpages has been performed to get data on Google Search and OnlineNewspaperlist.com. Finally, in order to have a common background on the topic, we wanted to analyse the number of refugees in the world in order to know how huge this political problem is all over the world. Data has been taken from WorldBank Data. 
These databases have several limitations and restrictions that should be considered beforehand, and that had also supposed some challenges to our project. 

- NewsAPI
    This API contains different limitations if you don't pay fror premium permisions.
    It retrieves data from past two months. 
    Furthermore, it only retrieves 5 pages for each topic you insert as a parameter. 
    The API has a source dataset that can be retrieved and then labeded. However, this API looks for data in sources that are not included in the source dataset. 
    
- World Bank Data 
    There are some gaps in the datasets, meaning that there is only only data from 1991 onwards. 
    There are some aggregated countries or areas that bias the final results and requires a careful data cleaning before performing any analysis. 


- Twitter API 


- Google Search 



- OnlineNewspaperlist.com

msg.data:
1.1. Databases Used

In order to develop this project, several databases have been used. First of all, Twitter API to get the tweets on this topic. Secondly, NewsAPI has been used as a source to get news from newspapers and digital newspapers. Later on, web scraping on diferent webpages has been performed to get data on Google Search and OnlineNewspaperlist.com. Finally, in order to have a common background on the topic, we wanted to analyse the number of refugees in the world in order to know how huge this political problem is all over the world. Data has been taken from WorldBank Data.
These databases have several limitations and restrictions that should be considered beforehand, and that had also supposed some challenges to our project.

  • NewsAPI
    This API contains different limitations if you don’t pay fror premium permisions.
    It retrieves data from past two months.
    Furthermore, it only retrieves 5 pages for each topic you insert as a parameter.
    The API has a source dataset that can be retrieved and then labeded. However, this API looks for data in sources that are not included in the source dataset.

  • World Bank Data
    There are some gaps in the datasets, meaning that there is only only data from 1991 onwards.
    There are some aggregated countries or areas that bias the final results and requires a careful data cleaning before performing any analysis.

  • Twitter API

  • Google Search

  • OnlineNewspaperlist.com

paragraphs.title: Fig.2 - Total news published on the past three weeks
paragraphs.text:
%sql 
SELECT date_new, source_id, count(title) FROM news GROUP BY source_id

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: Total news published by source
paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT  source.source_id,  source.name, count(news.source_id) AS total_news FROM news LEFT JOIN source ON news.source_id = source.source_id GROUP BY news.source_id ORDER BY total_news DESC LIMIT 5

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Visualizing the Twitter API information

Nowadays, Twitter’s total number of monthly active users is around 326 million, where 100 million are daily active users with an average of 500 million twits pe day, making it one of the most used social media platform globally. When talking about usage, almost 70% of the users use Twitter to read the news, making it the main focus of our study.

From the Twitter API, using the Standard Search method, we gathered approx. 42 thousand twits using “refugees” as our filter and English as the language for the twits. Ww got the hashtags, user_name, the twit text, and the location from the last 7 days. It is important to mention that the random variable location is made by the user when creating the account and in many repeated cases, the locations were not valid. For this reason, we had to select a couple of countries like Turkey, the United Kingdom, Germany, and Canada as our main focus and all the USA states individually. The selection of the countries is based on the most popular locations in our dataset, so a little bit of art and science.

### Data Wrangling

The process of data wrangling started with the main focus of fiding potential repeated rows, since we had to do two streaming request using the python library Twython Streaming method. After applyting methods to eliminate duplicates, we made sure that each observation was unique.

Moreover, to answer the questions of this analysis, we had to clean the locations columns. With this random variable we had to drop almost 39% of our data due to Null values. Furthermore, we had to select, based on the information obtain, a list of countries were the number of twits was greater than 30 twits after grouping by countries and US states. The country list contains locations like Turkey, Germany, The United Kingdom and Canada among others were we believe the refugees crisis have had a significant impact. For example, Turkey and Germany are hosting 3.4 million and 1.1 million refugees respectively out of the 25 million refugees acording to the United Nations Statistics.

Furthermore, as most of our data came from the United States, we decided that analysing the states separately had more meaning to our study than just concatenating them into just the USA as a whole. Based on this, we filter all the data to only included data from the mentioned countries and US states and compare them using ratios per million inhabitants to normalize the data as possible.

msg.data:
Visualizing the Twitter API information

Nowadays, Twitter’s total number of monthly active users is around 326 million, where 100 million are daily active users with an average of 500 million twits pe day, making it one of the most used social media platform globally. When talking about usage, almost 70% of the users use Twitter to read the news, making it the main focus of our study.

From the Twitter API, using the Standard Search method, we gathered approx. 42 thousand twits using “refugees” as our filter and English as the language for the twits. Ww got the hashtags, user_name, the twit text, and the location from the last 7 days. It is important to mention that the random variable location is made by the user when creating the account and in many repeated cases, the locations were not valid. For this reason, we had to select a couple of countries like Turkey, the United Kingdom, Germany, and Canada as our main focus and all the USA states individually. The selection of the countries is based on the most popular locations in our dataset, so a little bit of art and science.

Data Wrangling

The process of data wrangling started with the main focus of fiding potential repeated rows, since we had to do two streaming request using the python library Twython Streaming method. After applyting methods to eliminate duplicates, we made sure that each observation was unique.

Moreover, to answer the questions of this analysis, we had to clean the locations columns. With this random variable we had to drop almost 39% of our data due to Null values. Furthermore, we had to select, based on the information obtain, a list of countries were the number of twits was greater than 30 twits after grouping by countries and US states. The country list contains locations like Turkey, Germany, The United Kingdom and Canada among others were we believe the refugees crisis have had a significant impact. For example, Turkey and Germany are hosting 3.4 million and 1.1 million refugees respectively out of the 25 million refugees acording to the United Nations Statistics.

Furthermore, as most of our data came from the United States, we decided that analysing the states separately had more meaning to our study than just concatenating them into just the USA as a whole. Based on this, we filter all the data to only included data from the mentioned countries and US states and compare them using ratios per million inhabitants to normalize the data as possible.

paragraphs.title: Fig. 4 - Tweets per Million inhabitants
paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT * FROM twts_locs_count WHERE ratio_per_M > 10 ORDER BY ratio_per_M DESC

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md
In the Tweets per Million inhabitants table, we wanted to compare which country or US state was more active regarding twits mentioning the word “refugees”. As metioned before, the comparison is made by grouping per locations and then counting how many twits are in each on the locations of interest. After this, we made a ratio of twits per million inhabitant to have a fair comparison between the locations at hand.

From the graph we can see that New York leads the table with 42 twits per million inhabitants. This was a surprise for us since they do not have a refugee situation like Turkey or Germany. But we dig more into it and we can argument that New York is the capital of the world where a lot of public debate takes place, like in the United Nations Headquarters for example.

Moreover, Turkey, Texas and California are in the range of 12 and 16 twits with Turkey leading it. This group of countries have in common the fact that they are frontier states in the case of Texas and California with Mexico and Turkey is commonly known as the frontier between the Midlle East and Europe. It is safe to assume that the refugees crisis debate is significant in this places since they play an important role when dealing with this situation in the field as waves of refugees try to find their in into this country/states.

msg.data:
Unnamed: 0	hashtags	count
0	refugees	301
1	concentrationcamps	128
2	libya	113
3	standwithiraqirefugees	98
4	ice	98

paragraphs.text:
%md
After acknowledging the countries or US states were the crisis debate was significant active in twitter from the last 7 days using “refugees” as the filter. We wanted to see which Hashtags were more popular among the dataset. We do this by grouping hashtags and then counting and raking them to have at least hashtags with more than 50 counts in total.

As expected, “#refugees” was the most popular hashtag representing more than 50% of the second most popular hashtag, #concentrationcamps. For our surprise, #Lybia’s position in the top five was quite shocking since we were expecting Syria or Central American countries to be trending topic as most of our data consist on USA users. Moreover, #ICE fifth position turns out to be very significant for our study due to the major debate in the United States regarding the waves of illegal inmigrants inside the country or trying to get there in the last years. ICE, or the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement is a federal law enforcement agency in charge of enforcing immigrations laws and monitoring aliens in the USA territory. This agency has been under a lot of debate in the last couple of months due to the mistreating of illegal immigrants families and the lockup of childrens in “concentrations camps”.

paragraphs.title: Refugees hashtag count per Million inhabitants
paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT * FROM hashtags_refugees

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md
Once we obtain the most popular hashtag in our dataset, we wanted to know which location used it the most to see if we can find any relation between the hashtag #refugees and the location of origin.

In Turkey, the hashtag #refugees in mentioned 0.89 times per million inhabitants. As the euopean/asian country is leading in refugee count with 3.7 million of refugees, this insights confirms the fact the refugee crisis is quite debated in Twitter. Also, we could say that the trending topic in our dataset is influenced by the turkish users.

Furthermore, New Yorkers and Washingtonians are not far behind, with 0.7 and 0.6 mentions per million inhabitants. This add evidence to the assumption made before about the fact that NYC and Washington DC is a place where much of the political debate takes place.

news_ratio_country_path = '/home/ingrid/Documents/DA_Ironhack/Week3/Project-Week-3-Data-Thieves/your-project/In_tests/news_ratio_country.csv'
news_ratio_country = pd.read_csv(news_ratio_country_path)

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT tw.ratio_per_M as twt_ratio, ne.ratio_per_M as news_ratio, tw.locations FROM twts_locs_count_join as tw left JOIN news_ratio_country as ne ON tw.locations = ne.country ORDER BY  twt_ratio desc

%md
## Overall conclusions

Twitter is more than a social platform for people to watch videos and enjoy reading funny twits from comedians. It is an important place to debate, inform and read about current events like the global refugee crisis. Countries like Turkey, Germany and US states like New York, Texas, California and the Distric of Columbia are very concern about the crisis and users from this locations tent to be more active in tweeting and retweeting about this subject. Also, it is important to mention that frontier locations are also very active in informing and debating about the crisis as they are the ones who face it in first person.

msg.data:
Overall conclusions

Twitter is more than a social platform for people to watch videos and enjoy reading funny twits from comedians. It is an important place to debate, inform and read about current events like the global refugee crisis. Countries like Turkey, Germany and US states like New York, Texas, California and the Distric of Columbia are very concern about the crisis and users from this locations tent to be more active in tweeting and retweeting about this subject. Also, it is important to mention that frontier locations are also very active in informing and debating about the crisis as they are the ones who face it in first person.
